Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

Definition

Excessive ADH release leading to impaired water excretion and hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. (Option D)

Etiology
  • CNS disturbances: Stroke, infection, subarachnoid hemorrhage, etc.
  • Malignancies: Small cell lung cancer (most common), other cancers.
  • Drugs: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, SSRIs, "Ecstasy", NSAIDs, etc.
  • Surgery: Pain-induced ADH hypersecretion.
  • Pulmonary diseases: Pneumonia (Option A ruled out), respiratory failure, etc.
  • Hormone deficiency: Hypopituitarism, hypothyroidism.
  • HIV: Associated with infections.
  • Hereditary SIADH: V2 receptor mutation.

Pathophysiology
  • ADH function: Regulates water balance by controlling plasma osmolality; excess ADH causes water retention, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Volume regulation: In hypovolemia, ADH release is driven by volume receptors, worsening hyponatremia.

Clinical Presentation
  • Acute hyponatremia: Nausea, vomiting, headache, seizures, coma.
  • Chronic hyponatremia: Nonspecific symptoms (nausea, confusion, falls in elderly).

Diagnosis

Schwartz and Bartter Criteria:

  • Serum sodium <135 mEq/L (Option B)
  • Serum osmolality <275 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium >40 mEq/L
  • Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg (Option C)
  • The absence of clinical evidence of volume depletion (like normal skin turgor, blood pressure within the reference range)
  • The absence of hyponatremia due to other causes (like adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, cardiac failure, pituitary insufficiency, renal disease with salt wastage, hepatic disease, drugs that impair renal water excretion.)

Tests:

  • Renal function, serum osmolality, cortisol levels, thyroid tests, imaging for underlying causes.

Management
  • Fluid restriction: For mild to moderate symptoms.
  • Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, with careful correction rate (<8 mEq/L in 24 hrs).
  • Medications:
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Conivaptan, Tolvaptan)
    • Other: Loop diuretics, salt tablets, demeclocycline, lithium.

Complications
  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome: Risk from rapid sodium correction.
  • Severe hyponatremia: Can lead to seizures, coma, and death in acute cases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of episodes of palpitations, headache, and profuse sweating for the past few days. MIBG scan shows a deep-seated tumour in the adrenal medulla. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition described?

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical excision is the definitive treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension

options.label: D
options.text: Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen

questions.correct_answer: C. Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
questions.explanation:
Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Vomiting (Option D)
  • Pain abdomen
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines (Option A)
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines
  • Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (a metabolite of adrenaline and noradrenaline) (Option A)

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. (Option B)
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers (phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) (vs Option C)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

Hemodialysis is an indication for all the below conditions except?
questions.explanation:
Indication

Acute (AKI)

Chronic(CKD)

Fluid Overload
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Severe Hypertension
  • Edema resistant to diuretics

Hyperkalemia
  • >6.5 mmol/L with ECG changes (Broad QRS)
  • Potassium resistant to treatment

Uraemia
  • Pericarditis (Option D)
  • Encephalopathy (Option A)
  • Uremic syndrome (anorexia, nausea, lethargy, etc.), typically when eGFR < 10 mL/min/1.73 m²

Metabolic Acidosis

(Option C)
  • Severe acidosis(H+ > 79 nmol/L; pH < 7.1)
  • Chronic acidosis resistant to bicarbonate therapy

Relative indications
  • Bleeding diathesis due to uremia-induced platelet dysfunction
  • Intractable anemia despite erythropoietin and iron supplementation
  • Hyperphosphatemia despite phosphate binders

questions.text: Which of the following options represents the most severe manifestation of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Kidney Disease

Leading causes

  • Diabetic nephropathy (Most common)
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Hypertension
  • Ischemic heart disease (Cardiorenal syndrome)
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • Tubulointerstitial kidney disease

Manifestations
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea
  • Electrolyte Imbalances
  • Hiccups (urea irritates gastric mucosa)
  • Pedal oedema
  • Muscle cramping and twitching
  • Pruritus and skin pigmentation
  • Uremic fetor
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Uremic pericarditis
  • Hypertension

Fluid and serum electrolytes in CKD

Electrolyte Imbalances

Management

Hypervolemic hyponatremia:

  • High circulating aldosterone levels.
  • Increase in water > sodium retention.
  • Water restriction

Hyperkalemia
  • Patiromer
  • Calcium resonium
  • Sodium polystyrene
  • Calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (for cardiac protection).
  • Insulin and glucose (to shift potassium back into cells)

Hypokalemia (rare): Usually due to overuse of diuretics
  • Increase dietary intake and reduce the dose of diuretics

Hyperphosphatemia

  • Sevelamer
  • Calcium acetate or carbonate

Hypocalcemia
  • Paricalcitol

As the CBG valve of this patient showed 356mg/dL, the physician advises immediate ABG analysis, which reveals a pH=7.32, pCO 2 =38mEq/L, and HCO 3 -=15mEq/L. (NAGMA)

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis

  • Iron and isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis (Option B)
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning (Option D)
  • U: Urinary diversion / Ureterenterostomy

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with multiple oral and genital ulcers. The patient claims these ulcers resolve spontaneously and that she experiences such episodes at least four times a year. Ocular examination reveals features of anterior uveitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features

Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • Uveitis (>50%)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Nephrogenic DI

Feature

Central DI

Nephrogenic DI

Primary Polydipsia

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake, suppressing AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection has no effect on severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

Posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioral therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with palpitation and weight loss. On examination of her legs the following lesion was found which on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. ECG shows sinus rhythm. What is the probable cause of the oedema?
questions.explanation:
Nephrotic Syndrome

Clinical manifestations

Pathophysiology

Proteinuria

The damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to increased permeability to proteins.

Odema

Hypoalbuminemia
  • Due to urinary loss of albumin being more than its synthesis by the liver.
  • Muehrcke's lines (linear white lines in the nail bed seen in hypoalbuminemia)

Hyperlipidemia
  • Xanthoma and xanthelasma can be appreciated.

Hypercoagulability

This can be due to factors like:

  • Due to the loss of anticoagulant proteins like Protein C/ Protein S/ Antithrombin III
  • Ferritin deficiency
  • History of factor V Leiden mutation
  • Increased production of procoagulant factors by the liver.

Infections

Loss of immunoglobulins in urine causes hypogammaglobulinemia, increasing susceptibility to infections.

Diagnostic criteria for Nephrotic syndrome

Essential findings
  • Proteinuria of > 3.5 g/day
  • Urine PCR > 2g protein/g of creatinine
  • Hypoalbuminemia - serum Albumin < 2.5 gm%
  • Oedema due to reduced oncotic pressure

Other findings
  • Hypercholesterolemia,
  • Lipiduria
    • Urine microscopy: Oval fat bodies/Maltese cross bodies
  • Low eGFR
  • Hypercoagulability

questions.text: A hepatitis B-positive person came to your OPD on routine urine massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day). Further renal biopsy was performed as below. Identify the disease.

A chest x-ray shows widespread interstitial infiltrates in both lungs, and urine examination reveals the presence of cells with an 'owl-eye' appearance.
questions.explanation:
Complications following Renal transplant

Graft rejection

Hyperacute, acute and chronic

Opportunistic infections

 
  • < 1 Month: Wound infection, HSV, UTI, Oral candidiasis
  • 1-6 Months: CMV (most common), HBV, HCV, Pneumocystis carinii, Listeria
  • >6 Months: BK Virus, Aspergillus, Nocardia, HBV, HCV, HZV

Hypercalcemia

This may indicate failure of parathyroid gland regression post-transplant.

Anemia

Common post-transplant, often due to immunosuppressive medications. Gastrointestinal bleeding can occur from steroid use.

Chronic hepatitis

Particularly from hepatitis B virus, which can progress over time.

Skin and lip cancers

Most common malignancy

The leading causes of death among kidney transplant recipients include:

  • Cardiovascular events (29%)
  • Infections (18%)
  • Malignancies (17%)

questions.text: A patient exhibits symptoms of increased urination, nighttime urination, and involuntary urination, along with a recorded 24-hour urine volume of 7 litres. He has a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L. The ADH assay shows a recorded value of 0.8 pg/ml, and an MRI of the brain reveals the absence of a bright spot on T1-weighted imaging. questions.explanation:
Feature

Central DI

(Option C)

Nephrogenic DI

(Option A)

Primary Polydipsia

(Option B)

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake suppresses AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection does not affect severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

The posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioural therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment is usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with headache and cola-colored urine. His parents report throat pain 2 weeks ago. On examination, red blood cells are present in urine and his KFT is increased two fold. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)

Cause

Group A β-Hemolytic streptococci

Pathogenesis

Immune-complex mediated (Type III hypersensitivity reaction)

Clinical manifestations
  • It is more common in children and young adults.
  • History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks).
  • Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain)
  • Periorbital and pedal oedema
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy:
    • Abrupt rise in BP
    • Headache
    • Loss of consciousness
  • Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting.

Test for antibodies
  • Anti- DNAse
  • Anti-Hyaluronidase
  • ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer

Lab findings

  • Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark (cola-colored) on standing (hematuria).
  • Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc).
  • Raised serum potassium
  • Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50
  • Normal serum C4 level.

Pathological findings
  • Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys

 

  • Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells).

 

  • Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition)

 

  • Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition).

Management

  • Self-limiting disorder
  • Conservative and supportive management involves:
    • HTN crisis: Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside
    • Pulmonary edema: Furosemide
    • Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin)
    • Dialysis if needed

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used classify—
questions.explanation:
Criteria

AKI (Acute Kidney Injury) Criteria

RIFLE Criteria

KDIGO Criteria

Definition

A sudden decrease in kidney function or kidney damage that occurs within a short period, typically within 48 hours to 7 days.

RIFLE stands for Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease, representing different stages of kidney injury.

KDIGO provides guidelines for the evaluation and management of chronic kidney disease and acute kidney injury.

Parameters

- Increase in serum creatinine level by 0.3 mg/dL (26.5 μmol/L) within 48 hours

- Increase in serum creatinine level by ≥1.5 times from baseline

- Increase in serum creatinine level by ≥0.3 mg/dL (26.5 μmol/L) within 48 hours or increase by ≥1.5 times from baseline
 

- Increase in serum creatinine level to ≥1.5 times baseline within the past 7 days

- Urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for ≥6 hours (Oliguria)

- Urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours or longer
 

- Urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours or longer

    

Classification

AKI is classified into three stages:

RIFLE criteria are categorized into three levels:

KDIGO criteria are categorized into three stages:
 

- Stage 1: Increase in serum creatinine by 0.3 mg/dL or more or increase to 1.5-1.9 times the baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6-12 hours

- Risk: Serum creatinine increase ≥1.5 times or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours

- Stage 1: Increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL (26.5 μmol/L) or increase by ≥1.5-1.9 times from baseline
 

- Stage 2: Increase in serum creatinine to 2.0-2.9 times the baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for ≥12 hours

- Injury: Serum creatinine increase ≥2 times or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 12 hours

- Stage 2: Increase in serum creatinine by ≥2.0-2.9 times from baseline
 

- Stage 3: Increase in serum creatinine to ≥3 times the baseline or increase to ≥4.0 mg/dL or initiation of renal replacement therapy or urine output <0.3 mL/kg/h for ≥24 hours

- Failure: Serum creatinine increase ≥3 times or initiation of renal replacement therapy or urine output <0.3 mL/kg/h for ≥24 hours

- Stage 3: Increase in serum creatinine to ≥3 times baseline or increase to ≥4.0 mg/dL (354 μmol/L) or initiation of renal replacement therapy or urine output <0.3 mL/kg/h for ≥24 hours

Purpose

To identify and diagnose acute kidney injury, monitor its progression, and guide treatment decisions.

To assess the severity of kidney injury,

questions.explanation:
Type of Rejection

Hyperacute Rejection

Acute Rejection

Chronic Rejection

Acute Cellular Rejection

Acute Antibody-Mediated Rejection

Description
  • Occurs immediately after transplant.
  • Mediated by preformed antibodies against graft endothelial cells.
  • Occurs within days to weeks after transplant.
  • Mediated by CD8+ T cells and CD4+ T cells.

Antibodies bind to graft endothelial cells, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • Develops over months to years.
  • Mediated by T cells.

Timing

Minutes to hours after transplant.

Days to weeks after transplant.

Days to months after transplant.

Months to years after transplant.

Type of Hypersensitivity Reaction

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Immunologic Mechanism
  • Pre-existing antibodies activate complement.
  • Causes endothelial injury and thrombosis.
  • CD8+ T cells destroy graft cells.
  • CD4+ T cells induce inflammation.
  • Antibodies against graft antigens activate complement.
  • Leads to graft inflammation.

T cell-mediated response causes graft fibrosis and dysfunction.

Treatment
  • No treatment.
  • Requires graft removal.

Immunosuppressive therapy (steroids, antithymocyte globulin).

Plasmapheresis, IVIG, rituximab, steroids.
  • No definitive treatment.
  • Supportive care and immunosuppression.

What is the recommended treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Steroid-Responsive Nephrotic Syndrome

Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome

Definition

Nephrotic syndrome that responds well to corticosteroid treatment.

Nephrotic syndrome that does not improve despite adequate corticosteroid treatment (e.g., prednisolone at 2 mg/kg/day for 6 weeks).

Types:

  • Initial Steroid Resistance: Lack of response from the onset.
  • Late Steroid Resistance: Resistance develops after initial response.

Common Type

Minimal Change Nephrotic Syndrome (MCNS) accounts for about 80% of cases in children.

It is often associated with Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) or genetic mutations affecting podocytes.

Diagnosis

Diagnosed without kidney biopsy; characterised by heavy proteinuria, low serum albumin, and no significant glomerular damage.

Further investigation (e.g., kidney biopsy) is required to determine the underlying cause.

Management

Responds to high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone), leading to remission of proteinuria and oedema within 10-14 days.

Treatment may include immunosuppressive agents, calcineurin inhibitors, or other therapies, as corticosteroids are often ineffective.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine follow-up. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are normal, but she has microalbuminuria and an HbA1c of 8%. Her blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits, and she is currently on metformin for diabetes management. What should be the next step in her management?

options.label: C
options.text: Stop Metformin and start a different OHA

questions.explanation:
Management of Diabetic nephropathy

Oral Hypoglycemic agents (OHAs)
  • SGLT2 inhibitors lower the risk of cardiovascular events and renal failure; they are also recently approved for HFpEF.
  • For HbA1C < 9.5%, OHAs can be used
  • Metformin is withheld if eGFR is < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (Option C), and drugs safe in renal failure can be used like
    • Glipizide
    • Linagliptin
    • Repaglinide

Insulin

80% of the calculated dose is started if HbA1C > 9.5% (Option B)

Antihypertensives
  • In the presence of microalbuminuria, ACEi and ARBs have shown evidence to slow the progression of nephropathy if started in early stages.
  • In hypertension, for BP > 130/90, ACEi or ARBs are preferred
  • If BP is still not under control, Calcium channel blocker (CCB) can be added
  • Thiazide diuretic - in the presence of oedema (Option A)
  • If eGFR <30 ml/min, then the diuretic used - Metolazone.
  • ACEi/ARB comes with a side effect of hyperkalemia; hence, regular monitoring of potassium is necessary.
  • In the presence of hyperkalemia, ACEi/ARB is replaced by CCB
  • Alpha blocker (Prazosin) - hyperkalemia in ESRD.

For Hyperkalemia

K Binding resins (Bind to potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and promote its excretion)

  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate
  • Patiromer
  • Sodium zirconate

Renal Transplant

If eGFR is < 20 mL/min/1.73m2.

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).

questions.text: A young patient developed hyperpigmentation of distal fingers after being hospitalized post-adrenalectomy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Nelson syndrome

Definition

Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH. Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess.

Prevention

Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumours
  • Headache
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones

Evaluation

  • Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels:
    • Very high levels.
    • Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones.
  • Brain MRI shows pituitary tumours or enlargement of existing tumours.
  • Screening:
    • Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy.

Management

  • Surgical Removal of the Tumor
  • Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery
  • Medical Treatment
  • Hormonal Replacement Therapy

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - IV Mannitol:

Complications associated with Hemodialysis

During treatment

Between treatment
  • Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Muscle cramps.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts.
  • Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection.
  • Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction.
  • Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload).
  • Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula).
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure.
  • Amyloidosis (D/t beta 2 microglobulin)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum).
  • Peripheral neuropathy

  • DOC in management of Acute severe hyperkalemia (K+ > 6.5 mEq/L)

  • 10 U of IV Regular insulin
  • Usually followed by 50 mL 50% Dextrose
  • Most effective drug

Removal of K+
  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate: ADR - Intestinal necrosis
  • Sodium zirconate (ZS-9): more safer
  • Patiromer: Oral novel potassium binder
  • Loop & Thiazide diuretics: Furosemide, Hydrochlorothiazide
  • Hemodialysis: Most effective for K+ elimination, done for refractory hyperkalemia.
  • Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) & IV Normal saline

Renal Tubular Syndromes

Defect

Seen in

Cause

Effects

Fanconi Syndrome

Generalised reabsorption defect in PCT

Childhood
  • Hereditary defects (wilson disease, tyrosinemia, glycogen storage disease, cystinosis)
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Ischemia
  • Nephrotoxic drugs (ifosfamide, cisplatin, tenofovir, expired tetracycline)
  • Lead poisoning
  • Metabolic acidosis (proximal RTA)
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Phosphaturia
  • Osteopenia

Gitelman Syndrome (Option C)

  • Reabsorptive defect of NaCl- in DCT.
  • Mimics chronic thiazide diuretic use.

Late childhood or adulthood

Autosomal recessive
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypocalciuria

Bartter Syndrome (Option A)
  • Reabsorptive defect in thick ascending loop of Henle.
  • Affects Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter.
  • Mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Childhood

Autosomal recessive
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Hyperchloremia

Liddle Syndrome

Gain of function mutation → ↑ Na+ reabsorption in collecting tubules (↑ activity of Na+ channel)

 

Childhood

Autosomal dominant
  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypoaldosteronism

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Acute kidney injury:

Criteria

AKIN

RIFLE

Definition

Based on changes in serum creatinine and urine output.

Based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and GFR.

Serum Creatinine

Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours or ≥1.5 times baseline within 7 days.

R (Risk): Increase in serum creatinine ≥1.5 times baseline or GFR decrease >25%.

I (Injury): Increase in serum creatinine ≥2 times baseline or GFR decrease >50%.

F (Failure): Increase in serum creatinine ≥3 times baseline or GFR decrease >75%.

Urine Output

Decreased urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/hour for >6 hours).

O (Loss): Persistent acute kidney injury with complete loss of kidney function for >4 weeks.

E (End-stage kidney disease): Persistent acute kidney injury with complete loss of kidney function for >3 months.

Staging

AKIN stage 1: Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL or ≥1.5 times baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6-12 hours.

AKIN stage 2: Increase in serum creatinine ≥2 times baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour for ≥12 hours.

AKIN stage 3: Increase in serum creatinine ≥3 times baseline or serum creatinine ≥4.0 mg/dL or initiation of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or urine output <0.3 mL/kg/hour for ≥24 hours or anuria for ≥12 hours.

RIFLE classifies severity based on the R, I, F, O, and E criteria.

Clinical Application

Used in research, clinical trials, and clinical practice for AKI diagnosis and staging.

Widely used in research, clinical trials, and clinical practice for AKI diagnosis, classification, and outcome assessment.

Limitations

Relies on serum creatinine and urine output, which can be influenced by factors such as age, muscle mass, fluid status, and medications.

Similar limitations as AKIN criteria.

More recent studies suggest that RIFLE may be more predictive of mortality and need for RRT.
